name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to Classical South Asian Philosophy
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to Classical South Asian Philosophy
long_desc: Over the course of 3500 years, the Indian intellectual tradition has cultivated some of the most interesting theories of philosophy spanning formal logic, ethics, consciousness, and more. This introductory course to Classical Indian Philosophy begins with a background in Indian history, Sanskrit literature, and Dharmic religion before diving into rigorous approaches to epistemology  metaphysics by 9 separate schools of thought. Taught with an emphasis on inclass discussion and engagement with arguments put forward by Indian thinkers, this course also seeks to assist students in constructing an intellectual identity informed by their ethnohistorical context. Students with some background in computationalmathematical logic or analytic philosophy, as well as those of South Asian heritage, may especially enjoy this courses intersections with their prior knowledge.

custom_fields.goals: Learning objectivesDeepen critical thinking skills by engaging with complex and exotic ideas spanning logic, language, and metaphysics.Develop the fundamentals necessary for deeper study of Classical Indian history, literature, and philosophy.Learn how to construct an intellectual or ideological identity informed by cultural, ethnic, and ancestral contexts.Gain an appreciation for the logical sophistication and rich history of nonWestern intellectual traditions, namely those of the Indian Subcontinent since c. 1500 BC.
custom_fields.key_topics: Sanskrit, Indian Intellectual History & Literature, Ethics, Epistemology, Metaphysics, Religion, Philosophy, Language, India and Culture.
custom_fields.relevance: This course teaches South Asian students how to construct an intellectual or ideological identity informed by their cultural, ethnic, and ancestral contexts. It provides students of other backgrounds with an appreciation for the logical sophistication and rich history of non-Western intellectual traditions, namely those of the Indian Subcontinent since c. 1500 BC.
